title: Grouplet: A Structured Image Representation for Recognizing Human and Object Interactions

author: Bangpeng Yao, Computer Science Department, Stanford University

segmentation: Next speaker will be bank Pingyao and the title of the talk is in front of you so please OK.
So good morning everyone.
I'm going to present the group paper.
This is joining work with my advisor fairly.
Given a human and an object, we want to recognize their interactions, such as playing sax form.
However, this is not a trivial task because human object interaction cannot be fully understood by simply considering the Co occurrence of this human and the object.
In this case, it is possible that the human is holding their saxophone but not playing it.
Recognizing human object interaction has a wide range of applications such as sorry.
Such as teaching robots how to interact with objects, automatic sports commentary, visual analysis for medical care, and so on.
However, while recognition of both humans and generic objects has been extensively studied, the analysis of human object interaction has been mostly ignored.
Although there are some works that use image context to improve their recognition performance, the focus of those work is still human object recognition instead of the interaction between them.
In this talk, let's look into human object interaction in detail.
This is our outline.
Firstly the intuition.
Then we introduce the group feature representation and how are we going to use it for recognition.
And then we show some experiment results and conclusion.
OK, let's see our intuition.
Recognizing human object interaction is a very challenging problem.
Given this image where the human is playing saxophone.
The same interaction can be observed with different human posts, lighting and background.
Different interactions, such as playing bassoon, always have humans in a very similar post as playing saxophone.
Also, humans might interact very differently without same object, such as holding the saxophone but not playing it.
And given this very challenging problem, previous feature representations have some limitations.
For example, given the two images where the human is playing and not playing saxophone.
Bag of words or even special pyramid will produce very similar feature representations.
And in a pod based method such as Constellation model is also too coarse to tell the difference between the two images.
The reason is that from the Pixel label, the two images are very similar and only have some subtle difference.
So to address this problem in this work, we propose a novel feature representation called grouplet.
Group data is a part based feature and it explicitly considers the Co occurrence of different image parts.
It is also a discriminative and dense feature representation, so it is able to capture the subtle difference between different human object interactions.
Let's look into their group Leader feature representation in detail.
Given the image and the reference point, the GROUPLET considers the Co occurrence of a set of highly related image patches.
The group here contains 2 image patches, so we call it two group it.

Those image patches are encoded by Fisher units, and each feature unit considers the specific visual appearance and image location information, and the appearance is encoded by visual code word and the location is represented by a 2D Gaussian distribution.
And in the case of human object interaction we use the human face.
We use the center of the human face as a reference point.
And given this image, we want to recognize the interaction between the human and the object.
To it, so, we calculated the likelihood of preserving their grouplet in this image by computing the matching score between them.

And then because the group it encodes the color currents of different official units, so the matching score is measured by the minimum matching score between the image and each feature unit in this group it.
Given one feature unit, we consider the image patches in the neighborhood of the center of this Gaussian distribution and measure the likelihood of assigning each Patch to this visual code word.

And in order to allow the visual in order to allow the feature unit to be more resistant to small special variations, we consider multiple image locations in the small neighborhood of each feature unit.
So for each feature unit we will have a set of matching scores and the maximum value will be taken as the matching score between the future unit and this image.
To summarize, group leaders are part based feature where each part is associated with the feature unit within each group that we consider the color currents of different feature units.
And group it is a discriminative feature.
For example this group.
It can generally have large matching scores on images of playing saxophone and have small matching scores on images of the other interactions.
Also, group Lead is a dense and flexible fish.

Representation because official unit can be associated with all possible visual code words and densely sampled image locations and can have many possible variations of the spatial distribution and the group.
It can come up with many different combinations of feature units.

We propose a more efficient way to obtain the discriminative grouplets for each class.
Our solution is inspired by the apriori mining method.

By using a priority mining, when we mined thousands of group, it's the number of groups that we need to evaluate is only linear in the number of features units instead of the exponential number in the brute force way.
